newsitem.title: USA: Clinton backs campaign finance reform.
newsitem.headline: Clinton backs campaign finance reform.

text.p: President Clinton Tuesday challenged Republicans to agree to a bipartisan ban on large political contributions and renewed his endorsement of campaign finance reform legislation.

Speaking to the Democratic National Committee, Clinton said his party would stop accepting so-called "soft money" contributions if the Republican Party would do the same. These contributions are unlimited in size and are directed toward "party-building," rather than specific candidates, but critics say they give large donors undue influence on the political process.
Challenging Republicans to ban soft money, Clinton said: "If you will do it, we will do it. We have offered our hand again and again. Why not just say yes?"

Heavily criticized for the campaign financing tactics of himself and his party last year, Clinton also endorsed the reintroduction into Congress of a bipartisan bill to tighten rules for raising political funds sponsored by Arizona Republican Sen. John McCain and Wisconsin Democratic Sen. Russell Feingold.
"It is tough, it is balanced, it is credible. It should become the law of the land," Clinton said.
He chastised news media for their coverage of Democratic fundraising practices, saying Republicans were doing the same as Democrats and not receiving the same scrutiny.
